summary: This document is an email chain between prosecutors and defense attorneys in the US v. Maxwell case, discussing discovery issues related to photographic and video evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties. The correspondence focuses on the review, designation, and production of thousands of images, including 'Highly Confidential' materials containing nude or sexualized content, and logistical arrangements for defense access to evidence in Colorado and New York.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Prosecutor in the Southern District of New York corresponding with defense counsel about discovery production, including de-designation of FBI materials and arrangements for evidence review.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, raising issues about discovery deficiencies, access to 'Highly Confidential' images, and problems with viewing evidence at the MDC.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Defense counsel copied on email correspondence regarding discovery issues in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Defense counsel copied on email correspondence regarding discovery issues in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the US v. Maxwell case whose order (Dkt. No. 322) is referenced as the basis for the meet and confer discussion.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, referenced in relation to discovery materials being produced to her counsel and her ability to review documents at the MDC.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier whose New York residence was searched, leading to the seizure of CDs and devices containing the images and videos being discussed in discovery.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date
events.description: Trial date set for US v. Maxwell case, referenced in the context of when the prosecution would need to provide a list of 'Highly Confidential' photographs they may introduce.

events.title: FBI Report on Digital Evidence
events.description: FBI report indicating approximately 33,747 'Highly Confidential' images and 895 'Highly Confidential' videos were identified from CART-processed evidence from Epstein's devices.

events.title: Discovery Production
events.description: Reference to a production of discovery materials to the defense on November 9, 2020, containing spreadsheets and images.

events.title: Evidence Review in New York
events.description: Defense counsel traveled to New York to review evidence in the government's possession, including 'Highly Confidential' material on hard drives.

locations: 500 Pearl (likely a government building in NYC)
1 St. Plaza New York, NY 10007 (SDNY office)
150 10th Avenue Denver, CO 80203 (Haddon, Morgan & Foreman law office)
keyFacts: The FBI had approximately 40,000 images extracted from CDs seized from Jeffrey Epstein's New York residence, with about 3,400 initially designated as 'Highly Confidential' due to nudity.

A separate FBI review of Epstein's devices identified approximately 33,747 'Highly Confidential' images and 895 'Highly Confidential' videos, a number significantly higher than the 2,100 initially conveyed to defense counsel.
The prosecution was working to de-designate 'Highly Confidential' images that did not depict genitals, breasts, or buttocks, and planned to produce thousands of de-designated images to the defense.

Defense counsel reported significant technical problems with discovery, including corrupt files, unreadable photo formats, and difficulties matching metadata to images, hindering their ability to review evidence.

The FBI agreed to transfer hard drives containing highly confidential image/video files and boots (evidence items) to Colorado for defense review, but certain photographs had to remain in New York as they were logged as '1A items' with the case file.
